This video also demonstrates a principle of rifle bullets and the way that they are more deadly than handgun bullets.  Rifle bullets (generally) are longer.  This puts the center of pressure in front of the center of mass.  The bullet stays stable while it is supersonic, but as it drops below the speed of sound, it destabilizes and yaws as the rearward mass of the bullet is pushed forward.  The coefficient of friction also goes up in the trans-sonic phase, and helps create a larger cavitation.
No, it's still slow motion. "High Speed" only means that the sample rate of the camera is extremely fast so that you get smooth, nuanced slow motion.

I don't think that's air behind the bullet, it's a vacuum. The bullet pushes the water out of the way so quickly that it leaves a vacuum in its wake, and then the cavity implodes again after it passes.

That would make an excellent training video to illustrate wound ballistics in medicine. It shows the temporary wound cavity, the mushrooming of the bullet (which obviously happens with any bullet, just more controlled and consistent with hollow points) and the tumbling that often happens (don't know what kind of round that was) with rifle calibers (especially boat tail bullets).

@terminator499 Yes all bullets do to some degree. The general rule is the larger the caliber the more cavitation occurs. There are also bullets specifically designed to fire slower to cause more tumbling within the target as well as frangible bullets designed to break apart upon impact to reduce risk of ricochets and other safety concerns. Basic answer yes they will tumble, some more then others. How much depends on a lot of different factors.
